workflow.name: Export Amazon product reviews in bulk to Google Sheets via RapidAPI
workflow.description:
**What it does**
Pulls up to 700 Amazon reviews per product (recent and top-rated) and writes them straight into a Google Sheet tab you choose.

**Perfect for**
‚Ä¢ Brand and product managers tracking sentiment
‚Ä¢ Marketplace sellers analysing competitor feedback
‚Ä¢ Agencies building product-review dashboards

**Apps used**
RapidAPI Real-Time Amazon Data, Google Sheets, n8n Form Trigger

**How it works**

1. Form Trigger collects brand, product and sheet info.
2. Code node extracts the ASIN and builds 70 API requests (10 pages √ó star ratings).
3. Split-in-batches loops through the request list, throttled by two Wait nodes.
4. HTTP Request fetches reviews from RapidAPI.
5. IF node drops empty or error responses.
6. Split Out breaks arrays into single reviews.
7. Google Sheets appends every review to the target tab.
8. Loop continues until all pages finish.

**Setup**

1. Fill in **Brand name, Product / Model Name, Amazon Product URL, Tab URL to insert reviews** in the form.
2. Grab your `X-RapidAPI-Key` from RapidAPI ‚Üí **Add as httpHeaderAuth credential**.
3. Connect Google Sheets OAuth2 and make the spreadsheet **Anyone with the link can edit**.
4. Open Workflow Settings ‚Üí set timezone if you plan to schedule runs.
5. Hit *Execute workflow* or share the form link.

**Credentials**
‚Ä¢ Real-Time Amazon Data (RapidAPI HTTP Header Auth)
‚Ä¢ Google Sheets OAuth2

**Limits and notes**
‚Ä¢ \~100 RapidAPI calls for the free plan. Plan quota accordingly.
‚Ä¢ Assumes Amazon returns 10 pages per star rating; fewer pages skip silently.
‚Ä¢ Large sheets may hit Google API write quotas.


**If you have any questions in running the workflow, feel free to reach out to me at my youtube channel:** https://www.youtube.com/@hunyaochong

sheetName.value: ={{ $('On form submission').item.json["Tab URL to insert reviews"] }}

parameters.formDescription: Which brand's feedback would you like to research on?

parameters.content:
## üßæ Amazon Product Reviews Scraper ‚Äì User Manual

### üì• 1. On Form Submission

* When filling in the form, ensure that the **Tab URL** entered matches the **exact URL** of the corresponding tab in the Google Sheet you want to populate.
* If there's a mismatch, the data **will not be stored** in the correct sheet.

---

### üîç 2. What This Workflow Does

* For each ASIN, the scraper pulls:

  * **MOST RECENT** reviews ‚Üí 100 per star rating (1‚≠ê to 5‚≠ê)
  * **TOP REVIEWS** ‚Üí 100 for only 1‚≠ê and 5‚≠ê
* This means:

  * 50 API calls for MOST RECENT (5 ratings √ó 10 pages each)
  * 20 API calls for TOP REVIEWS (2 ratings √ó 10 pages each)
  * **Total: 70 API calls per product**

---

### üîë 3. How to Get Your RapidAPI Key

1. Go to: [RapidAPI Playground](https://rapidapi.com/letscrape-6bRBa3QguO5/api/real-time-amazon-data/playground/endpoint_1e42cec2-07bd-49bf-bde6-563c03f27bb3)
2. Log in or sign up for a RapidAPI account.
3. Click **"Test Endpoint"** ‚Üí this auto-generates your API Key.
4. Click the **‚ÄúCode Snippet‚Äù** tab ‚Üí copy your `X-RapidAPI-Key`.
5. Paste this into your n8n HTTP Request credentials under `httpHeaderAuth`.

---

Here‚Äôs the updated section with the correct error message:

---

### ‚ö†Ô∏è 4. Known Failure Cases

#### üî∏ *Fails at* ‚Üí `If status "OK" and contains reviews`

Two main causes:

1. **Not enough reviews available**
   The workflow assumes **10 pages** of reviews exist for each star rating.
   If Amazon doesn't have that many, the step will fail silently at the conditional check.

2. **RapidAPI quota limit exceeded**
   If you've hit your monthly quota, the API will return an error like:

   ```
   The service is receiving too many requests from you  
   You have exceeded the MONTHLY quota for Requests on your current plan, BASIC.  
   Error 429
   ```

   You can verify this by checking the logs for an `Error 429` and reviewing your quota at [RapidAPI Dashboard](https://rapidapi.com/developer/dashboard).

user.name: Hunyao
user.bio:
Hun Yao is a founder-engineer obsessed with building scalable automation that actually moves the needle - with a focus in the E-commerce space. 

A self-taught product builder with roots in marketing and AI, he uses n8n as his playground to ship MVPs fast - turning modular workflows into elegant, revenue-generating systems.

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
